Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Uncovering the Dynamics and Functionality of Origami Structures and Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Origami is the ancient art of folding paper into decorative shapes and geometries. Over the last several decades, it evolved and became a design framework for many engineering and architecture applications. Examples include deployable space structures, kinetic buildings, self-folding robots, surgery devices, and advanced materials. Origami folding so far has been considered as a static process. People typically focus on its design and geometry, or internal actuation mechanisms that makes the folding autonomous. This award supports a collaborative project that will investigate the fundamental dynamic characteristics of origami folding. In particular, the research will explore how to harness the extraordinary properties of origami for applications like vibration isolation at low frequency, recoverable impact absorption, and impulsive actuation. Furthermore, the research will produce design tools that can generate sophisticated folding patterns and assign material properties that are suitable for a wide variety of dynamic performance requirements. The results of this project will become the building blocks for the next generation of air, marine, and land vehicles, intelligent machines and robots, or smart infrastructures, enhancing their functionality, safety and sustainability. The findings will thus advance the aerospace, civil, mechanical, robotics and many other industries. Education and broadening participation plans will focus on student learning and community outreach at various levels and on the enhancement diversity through inclusion in the research activities of members of underrepresented minorities in science and engineering.

This research will, for the first time, rigorously investigate the dynamic characteristics of origami folding and develop its corresponding engineering potentials. Preliminary studies have discovered that origami with generic crease patterns exhibits many attractive properties via folding, such as zero/negative stiffness, pressure dependent multi-stability, and piece-wise stiffness jump. Such surprisingly rich properties and the corresponding dynamic responses will be analyzed in detail based on an equivalent truss-frame model, which transforms the continuous origami structure into a finite degree of freedom system. The truss frame model would also become the basis of a comprehensive synthesis tool that incorporates crease perturbation and optimization, so that the origami can be customized for prescribed dynamic performances. This synthesis tool will bridge the currently separated branches of studies: the mathematical theories of origami design/folding and the engineering of origami based applications. Overall, the new modeling, analysis and synthesis tools for origami dynamics will create a significant intellectual leap and build a strong foundation for many future related research and development efforts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Origami -- the ancient art of paper folding -- has become a popular subject among artists, architects, mathematicians, and engineers.  Origami-inspired educational tools, foldable structures, and packaging solutions are shaping our modern life in many unique ways.  However, we have been limiting ourselves to exploiting the geometry and shape change (aka. kinematics) of folding.  It is not until the recent five years that we started to uncover the potentials of harnessing the mechanics and dynamics of origami-based structures and materials.


This project supported a pioneering and systematic study into the dynamics of origami folding.  The Clemson research team derived new analytical models to describe the time and frequency responses of reciprocal folding motions of different origami designs.  By using this new model, they were able to examine the unique mechanical properties induced by folding, such as quasi-zero stiffness, strain-softening behavior, and bi-stability.   Understanding these folding-induced properties made it possible to use origami for a wide range of dynamic applications that we never attempted before.  For example, quasi-zero stiffness is ideal for use in low-frequency vibration isolation. Therefore, we can apply folded origami as the base for engines or buildings and protect them from harmful ambient vibrations like an earthquake.  Strain-softening behavior in origami can help us to store more energy than a simple spring in compression.  Thus, the Clemson team folded modular, compact, and "springy" robotic legs, which exhibited high-performance jumping by launching itself five times higher than its resting height.  Also, the Clemson team found a way to use harmonic excitations to fold multi-stable origami rapidly from one stable equilibrium to another.  In this way, one can apply excitations of different frequencies to fold the origami to different shapes.


A unique advantage of these applications is that the folding-induced dynamics directly correlates to the seemingly infinite possibilities in origami design.  The Clemson team showed that, by tailoring the crease pattern, one could easily prescribe the origami dynamics according to different application requirements.   The analytical tool they developed can provide critical design guidelines.    Moreover, such a close correlation to geometry makes it feasible to scale the desirable dynamics to different sizes.  Therefore, the outcome of this research could foster a new generation of origami-inspired structures, materials, and robotics to advance our aerospace, manufacturing, and robotics industry.


Besides the engineering applications, the results of this project also enriched origami as an engaging, flexible, and inexpensive education tool.   Paper folding is proven effective for STEM teaching at pre-school, K-12, and even college level.  Teaching with origami can improve students' spatial thinking and geometric reasoning skills, help to close the gender gaps in the STEM workforce, and provide inexpensive education for low-income communities with a high percentage of the minority population. 


However, educators have been traditionally using paper folding to teach mathematics and geometry only.  The new knowledge created by this research makes it possible to use origami to teach engineering fundamentals in mechanics and dynamics.  The Clemson team has initiated these educational work by showcasing origami-inspired engineering at the local art fair, teaching engineering principles to high school students through folding, and offering short courses on origami mechanics at international conferences and college campuses.  Their work demonstrated the effectiveness of using origami to teach engineering mechanics and dynamics.  Therefore, these educational outcomes could have lasting impacts by inspiring future generations to pursue their careers in science and engineering fields.
